results.title: Tour of duty
results.creator_credit: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While he saw it as his duty to defend his country against communism, it wasn’t until Paul Rayment went to Vietnam that he realised how lucky Australia really was. However, on his return, Rayment became estranged from his community and friends, and it took a while to rebuild those ties and his connection to the country he had earlier set out to defend.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Leave no man behind
results.creator_credit: Les Maher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Even though Les Maher believed you should never leave a man behind, there was a time in Vietnam that he had to make the decision to do so. Decades later, Maher has never forgotten and endeavoured to fulfil his promise.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Les Maher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Boy who came in from the cold
results.creator_credit: Jack Darling, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alfred (Jack) Darling was a gunner on the ANZAC during the Korean War. The boys came up with as many ways as possible to overcome the Korean winter, including growing a beard, which required permission from the captain.

results.title: Sink or swim
results.creator_credit: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Gwynneth Cole joined the army in 1944, roles for women were limited. While Cole didn’t get to serve on the front line, she was posted to different bases in Australia as a nurse and faced many hardships and the realities of war. Cole greatly values her time in the army and reflects on the opportunities for women and the independent streak she has passed on to her four daughters.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Singapore dollars
results.creator_credit: Edward Dunstan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edward Dunstan served in the Australian Navy for 20 years, spending a significant part of that time in Singapore. While he enjoyed his time there, Dunstan also has some bad memories, not least of all was how he was received by his fellow Australians on his return. However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edward Dunstan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Edward Dunstan served in the Australian Navy for 20 years, spending a significant part of that time in Singapore. While he enjoyed his time there, Dunstan also has some bad memories, not least of all was how he was received by his fellow Australians on his return. However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.

While he enjoyed his time there, Dunstan also has some bad memories, not least of all was how he was received by his fellow Australians on his return. However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.

results.title: An Interview with Laurie Price
results.creator_credit: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.

results.title: An Interview with John Balloch
results.brief_description: John Balloch was at school when war was declared. Even so, he couldn’t wait to sign up. He wanted to be a fighter pilot, flying alone. He tells of his training and time serving in the RAAF during World War II and pays tribute to those lost, both to the enemy and accidents.
results.description: John Balloch was at school when war was declared. Even so, he couldn’t wait to sign up. He wanted to be a fighter pilot, flying alone. He tells of his training and time serving in the RAAF during World War II and pays tribute to those lost, both to the enemy and accidents.

results.title: An Interview with Jan McCarthy
results.brief_description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.
results.description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.

In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.

results.title: An Interview with Jack Jones
results.brief_description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.
results.description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.

Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. results.title: An Interview with Harold Brown
results.brief_description: Harold Brown reflects fondly on his time in the army. Joining the artillery division in 1942, he was posted to Bougainville, where disease was more of a threat to the soldiers than the Japanese. Despite longing to be back home with his newborn son, Brown could not have wished to be with a better crew.
results.description: Harold Brown reflects fondly on his time in the army. Joining the artillery division in 1942, he was posted to Bougainville, where disease was more of a threat to the soldiers than the Japanese. Despite longing to be back home with his newborn son, Brown could not have wished to be with a better crew.
